questions.text: A client presents with muscle twitching, hand tremors, and positive Chvostek's sign. Which electrolyte imbalance is this indicative of?
questions.solution:
Hypocalcemia causes increased neuromuscular excitability by decreasing the threshold needed for activation of neurons. As a result, neurons become unstable and fire spontaneous action potentials leading to involuntary contraction of the muscles eventually causing tetany. Latent tetany can be diagnosed by maneuvers such as:

  • Chvostek sign (twitching of the orbicularis oculi and mouth elicited by tapping the facial nerve anterior to the external auditory meatus) and
  • Trousseau sign (carpopedal spasm elicited by inflating the arm blood pressure cuff above the systolic pressure for 3 min).

Other options -

  • Hyperkalemia presents with nausea, vomiting and paresthesias nonspecific findings of muscle weakness (skeletal, respiratory), fatigue and ileus.
  • Hypercalcemia presents as either asymptomatic or may have vomiting, hypotonia, hypertension or seizures.
  • Hypokalemia presents as muscle weakness (neck flop, abdominal distension, ileus) and cardiac arrhythmias.

Topic: Electrolyte imbalances

Reference: GHAI Essential Pediatrics, 10th edition, Chapter-6, Page-66

questions.text: All of the following forms the immediate management of hyperkalemia except?
questions.solution:
Magnesium sulphate is used for hypomagnesemia.

Other options -

  • 10% calcium gluconate - Stabilize myocardial cell membrane to prevent cardiac arrhythmia.
  • Regular insulin and glucose - Enhance cellular uptake of potassium
  • B-adrenergic agonists (salbutamol, terbutaline) nebulized or IV - Enhance cellular uptake of potassium

Other Drugs used are:

  • Sodium bicarbonate
  • Sodium polystyrene sulfonate (Kayexalate)
  • Loop or thiazide diuretics
  • Hemodialysis

Topic: Electrolyte imbalance

Reference: GHAI Essential Pediatrics, 10th edition, Chapter-6, Page-65

questions.text: A patient with hyperkalemia may display which of the following ECG changes?
questions.solution:
ECG changes appear progressively with rising serum K+ and include tall, peaked T waves (5.5 to 6.5 mEq/L), prolonged PR interval, flat P waves, wide QRS complex (6.5 to 8.0 mEq/L), absent P waves, bundle branch blocks and eventually sine waves (>8.0 mEq/L).

Topic: Electrolyte imbalance

Reference: GHAI Essential Pediatrics, 10th edition, Chapter-6, Page-65

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter-97, Page-555

questions.text: A 5 year old presents with history of fever on and off for past 2 weeks and petechial spots all over the body and increasing pallor for past 1 month. Examination reveals splenomegaly of 2 cm below coastal margin. The most likely diagnosis-
questions.solution:
Signs and symptoms of bone marrow failure with the occurrence of pallor, fatigue, exercise intolerance, bruising, oral mucosal bleeding or epistaxis, and organomegaly and intermittent low-grade fever points towards infection or the leukemia.

Other options -

  • Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura - Antibody related destruction of platelets leading to thrombocytopenia. Splenomegaly is not seen in ITP.
  • Hypersplenism and Aplastic anemia - It is acute emergency with abrupt onset. Chronic fever rules out hypersplenism.

Topic: Hematological malignancies

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter-544, Page-3098

questions.text: Which of the following presents as mediastinal enlargement -
questions.solution:
Acute lymphocytic leukemias are the most common malignant neoplasms in childhood, with signs and symptoms of bone marrow failure, bone pain and Organ infiltration (commonly mediastinum, testis and CNS)

Option A: Promyelocytic leukemia(APML) or AML M3 presents with a DIC like picture and is associated with t(15;17) or PML:RARA translocation.

Option B. CML and Option D. Diffuse histocytic lymphoma do not present with mediastinal involvement.

Topic: Hematological malignancies

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter-544, Page-3098

questions.text: A 26 years old mother who is breastfeeding her baby comes to your OPD with complaint of left sided breast swelling as well as pain and history of improper latching. No nodular structure or pus discharge is seen and the breast appears to be full. What can be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Mastitis occurs in 2-3% of lactating women and is usually unilateral, manifesting with localized warmth, tenderness, edema, and erythema after the 2nd post delivery week. Sudden onset of breast pain, myalgia, and fever with fatigue, nausea, vomiting, and headache can also occur.

Organisms implicated in mastitis include Staphylococcus aureus, Escherichia coli, group A streptococcus, Haemophilus influenzae, Klebsiella pneumoniae, and Bacteroides species.

Other options -

  • Nipple pain occurs due to Poor infant positioning and improper latch and is visible clinically well.
  • Breast abscess is more serious, with pus discharge and needs iv antibiotics, incision and drainage, along with temporary cessation of feeding from that breast.
  • Fibroadenoma is clinically seen with nodular structure.

Topic: Breast feeding

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 61, Page 411

Topic: Breastfeeding

Reference: K E Elizabeth, 5th ed/18

questions.text: The most commonly used index for nutritional status is
questions.solution:
Weight-for-age is the most commonly used index of nutritional status, although a low value has limited clinical significance because it does not differentiate between wasting and stunting. Weight-for-age has the advantage of being somewhat easier to measure than indices that require height measurements.

Other options -

  • Height-for-age: a measure of linear growth and a deficit represents the cumulative impact of adverse events, resulting in stunting, or chronic malnutrition.
  • Weight-for-height, or wasting: lower value usually indicates acute malnutrition.
  • Body mass index (BMI) is calculated by dividing weight in kilograms by the square of height in meters. For children, BMI is age and gender specific. BMI-for-age is a screening tool for thinness (less than -2 SD), overweight (between +1 SD and +2SD), and obesity (greater than +2 SD).

Topic: Malnutrition

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 64, Page 433

choices.text: Failure to gain appetite by day 10
Failure to gain at least 5 g/kg/day by day 4
Failure to gain at least by 20 g/kg/day in rehabilitation phase

questions.text: Poor indicator to response during treatment of malnutrition includes-
questions.solution:
Primary failure to respond is indicated by: (OPTIONS CORRECTION)

  • Failure to regain appetite by day 4
  • Failure to start losing edema by day 4
  • Presence of edema by day 10
  • Failure to gain weight of at least 5 g/kg/day by day 10

Secondary failure to respond is indicated by

  • Failure to gain at least 5 g/kg/day in rehabilitation phase

Topic: Malnutrition

Reference: OP Ghai essential pediatrics, 10th edition, chapter 7, Nutrition, page 92

questions.text: Rickets in infant present as all Except-
questions.solution:
Bow legs is caused by general softening of the bones, causes them to bend easily when subject to forces. However it is manifested when the child starts walking due to weight bearing stress to demineralized rickety bones, not in infants.

Other options -

  • Craniotabes: softening of the cranial bones and can be detected by applying pressure at the occiput or over the parietal bones. The sensation is similar to the feel of pressing into a Ping-Pong ball and then releasing.
  • Rachitic rosary: Widening of the costochondral junctions, which feels like the beads of a rosary as the examiner's fingers move along the costochondral junctions from rib to rib.

Topic: Individual deficiency disorders

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 69, Page 470

questions.text: Thiamine deficiency leads to all except:
questions.solution:
Pellagra is the classic niacin deficiency disease.

Other options - All occur due to thiamine deficiency:

  • Beriberi: peripheral neuritis (manifesting as tingling, burning, and paresthesias of the toes and feet), decreased deep tendon reflexes, loss of vibration sense, tenderness and cramping of the leg muscles, heart failure, and psychologic disturbances.
  • Wernicke encephalopathy: mental status changes, ocular signs, and ataxia
  • Megaloblastic anemia: Megaloblastic anemia, diabetes mellitus, and sensorineural hearing loss

Topic: Individual deficiency disorders

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 67, Page 459

questions.text: Keshan disease is due to deficiency of:
questions.solution:
Dietary selenium deficiency is associated with cardiomyopathy known as Keshan disease and myopathy.

Other options -

  • Copper deficiency - Microcytic anemia, osteoporosis, neutropenia, neurologic symptoms, depigmentation of hair and skin
  • Zinc deficiency - Decreased growth, dermatitis of extremities and around orifices, impaired immunity, poor wound healing, hypogonadism, diarrhea
  • Manganese deficiency - Hypercholesterolemia, weight loss, decreased clotting proteins

Topic: Individual deficiency disorders

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 72, Page 483

questions.text: Which of the following organ doesn't have any role in regulating Vitamin D metabolism?
questions.solution:
Lung is not involved in Vitamin D metabolism

Other options -

  • Skin: Vitamin D can be synthesized in skin epithelial cells and is normally the most important source of vitamin D and depends on the conversion of 7-dehydrochlesterol to vitamin D3 (3-cholecalciferol) by ultraviolet B (UVB) radiation from the sun.
  • Liver: Vitamin D is transported bound to vitamin D-binding protein to the liver, where 25-hydroxlase converts vitamin D into 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25-D), the most abundant circulating form of vitamin D.
  • Kidney: The final step in activation occurs in the kidney, where the enzyme 1α-hydroxylase adds a second hydroxyl group, resulting in 1,25-D. The 1α-hydroxylase is upregulated by PTH and hypophosphatemia and inhibited by hyperphosphatemia and 1,25-D. Most 1,25-D circulates bound to vitamin D-binding protein.

Topic: Individual deficiency disorders

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 69, Page 474
